newsitem.title: MACAU: Macau passes tough law to combat surging crime wave.
newsitem.headline: Macau passes tough law to combat surging crime wave.

text.p: Portuguese-ruled Macau on Thursday passed a tough law to fight Chinese gangsters and to crack down on a wave of violent crime, assassinations and fire bombing that has rocked the territory in recent months.
Macau's legislature overwhelmingly endorsed the law, which is directed against triads, or secret criminal societies, that comes into effect early next month.

The 42-article bill is modelled on Italy's anti-Mafia laws and imposes prison terms of up to 15 years for leaders of triads. Tougher prison sentences would be meted out to gang leaders, or "dragonheads", for recruiting members under the age of 18.
The bill also imposes a ban on the entry to the enclave of convicted foreign triad members.
It offers special protection to detectives infiltrating triads or to gangsters giving evidence against kingpins.

But one pro-democracy legislator, Ng Kuok-cheong, expressed concern that human rights protection would be eroded under the new law, which makes it an offence to disturb people's "well being or feeling of security". He said the government should narrow the definition.

Triads, some of them well-organised, operate in Hong Kong, Macau and southern China, and their tentacles stretch to Chinatowns in a number of Western countries. Macau gangsters often escape into China after carrying out attacks.

They are linked to a wide range of illegal activities ranging from drugs trafficking, smuggling and prostitution to protection rackets, which the new anti-triad law has listed as types of crimes specific to triads.
In Macau, which earns most of its foreign currency from gambling-related tourism, the triads run protection rackets preying on the casino business.
Gang warfare has been blamed for a recent wave of bombings, arson attacks and drive-by shootings in which some 16 people have been killed so far this year.
The number of tourists visiting Macau fell 2.4 percent to 3.2 million in the first five months this year versus the same period of 1996.
Police sources say two gangs -- the 14K and Soi Fong -- are believed to have forged a truce in May after realising that gangland-style killings were bad for business.
Macau, under Portuguese rule for four-and-a-half centuries, reverts to Chinese rule in 1999.
Beijing has urged the Portuguese authorities to crack down on organised crime before the handover, and Macau and Chinese police have been liaising on the problem.
